history.content:
Finding the right subproblem depends on the problem and can take some experimentation.

For example, prefix/suffix can be used when smaller subproblems can be expanded from the beginning/end to the end/beginning (e.g. hotel stops, max contiguous subsequence, longest common substring). Substring can be used when the subproblems expand outward towards the beginning and end of the input rather than expanding in one direction (e.g. longest palindrome, matrix multiply).

For matrix multiplication, the optimal order of multiplying matrices $$X_i, ..., X_j$$ is computed by considering multiplication of different matrix subgroups $$\left(X_i * ... * X_k\right)*\left(X_{k+1} * ... * X_j\right)$$.  A prefix subproblem could tell you the cost of the left subgroup $$\left(X_i * ... * X_k\right)$$, but not the right subgroup $$\left(X_{k+1} * ... * X_j\right)$$, so substrings are more natural to use in this case.

I need some clarity on what prefixes and substrings are to make sure I understood them correctly.

So a prefix as I understand it is something like a_1......a_j  when a goes from a_1 to a_n

A suffix is something like a_j......a_n for the same interval

then a substring is like a_i....a_j for the same interval

Could you explain how I'd be able to tell which is most appropriate to use? I was looking at the chain matrix multiplication lectures and this lesson confused me.
history.subject: Prefixes and Substrings
